thirty-seven
composed by five hundred great arhats and others
tripiá¹­aka master Xuanzang respectfully received
What is its own nature?
Answer: Wisdom is its own nature.
If so, why is it named after thought?
Because the function of thought is increased in this aggregate.
Like mindfulness of breathing and mindfulness of the body,
mindfulness arises by its own nature.
Recollection of past lives,
all have wisdom as their essence.
They are named after mindfulness.
Because the function of mindfulness is increased.
They are also like this. The essence has already been explained.
One should explain its name.
Why is it called the elimination of the thought of form?
Because it can dispel all accumulated forms and prevent them from appearing,
it is called the elimination of the thought of form.
The realm is the form realm.
The stage is the fourth meditative absorption.
The basis is the body of the desire realm.
The aspect is the aspect of unclear activity.
The object is the desire realm.
Question: What dharmas in the desire realm does this take as its object?
Answer: Some say:
It takes the pit, etc. as its object.
Some say:
It takes the space element in that place as its object.
Those who say this:
It takes as its object all the forms that are excluded.
Among them, some say:
It only takes as its object the forms of one's own body that are excluded. The mindfulness of the body is the mindfulness of the body.
The cognition is conventional cognition.
The samÄdhi is not associated with samÄdhi.
The faculties are associated with the faculty of equanimity. As for the time periods, it is common to all three time periods.
In the past, it takes the past as its object.
In the present, it takes the present as its object.
As for the future, that which can arise
Takes the future as its object.
That which does not arise takes the three time periods as its object.
As for wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate,
The wholesome takes the three kinds as its object.
Some say:
It only takes the indeterminate as its object.
As for being bound to the three realms and not being bound,
It is bound to the form realm.
It takes that bound to the desire realm as its object.ğŸ”½As for the learner, post-learner, and neither learner nor post-learner,
It is neither the learner nor the post-learner.
Taking non-learners and non-post-learners as objects.
Those that are eliminated by insight and those eliminated by cultivation, and those that are not eliminated.
They are eliminated by cultivation.
They take what is eliminated by cultivation as objects.
Taking one's own body, others' bodies, and non-bodies as objects.
Some say:
Only taking one's own body as objects.
Some say:
Taking one's own body and others' bodies as objects.
Some say:
Universally taking all three kinds as objects.
Taking names and meanings as objects.
Only taking meanings as objects.
Attained through practice and attained through detachment.
They are attained through practice.
Not attained through detachment.
Those who have already become detached from the defilements of the fourth meditation.
If one does not practice seeking this thought,
One will never be able to give rise to it and make it manifest. Some say:
The Buddha attains it through detachment.
Because he attains it when he becomes detached from the defilements of the peak of existence.
The rest are attained through practice.
Some say:
The rest are also attained through detachment.
But they manifest through practice.
The Buddha does not practice. The Solitary Buddha practices less.
The Hearers may be in the middle or above.
As for the place where it arises, it is in the desire realm.
Not in the form or formless realms.
It is in the three continents of humans, not in the northern continent.
Question: Who gives rise to this?
Answer: Some say only the noble ones, not ordinary beings.
Some say:
Ordinary beings also give rise to it.
There are two kinds of ordinary beings:
1. Ordinary beings of the inner teaching.
2. Ordinary beings of the outer teaching.
Those of the inner teaching can give rise to it, not those of the outer teaching.
Because ordinary beings of the outer teaching
For a long time grasp at self and fear non-self.
They do not enjoy eliminating the internal basis of form.
Having already explained the nature and so forth of this perception, it should be further shown whether it is mixed or not.
Question: Do all those who have no perception of form have not yet become free from attachment to form?
Answer: All those who have not yet become free from attachment to form have no perception of form.
There are those who have no perception of form but have not yet become free from attachment to form.
Namely, those who have become free from attachment to form but have not yet entered that concentration.
Question: Do all those who have a perception of form have already become free from attachment to form?
Answer: Those who have eliminated the notion of form have all already separated from attachment to form.
There are those who have already separated from attachment to form but do not have the elimination of the notion of form.
This refers to those who have already separated from attachment to form but have not yet entered that concentration.
Why is this so?
It is said that this concentration is only attained through added effort.
It is not attained through separation from defilements.
Even though one has already separated from attachment to the fourth dhyana,
if one does not seek this concentration through added effort,
one will never be able to give rise to it and make it manifest.
Some say:
Although this concentration is attained through separation from defilements,
pratyekabuddhas and others must give rise to added effort in order to make it manifest.
This is said based on whether it is present or not.
Question: There are many places where it is said to eliminate the notion of form.
This is said in the Saá¹ƒyukta Ä€gama,
and it is also said that entering the formless concentrations removes the notion of form.
Varaá¹‡Ä also says this:ğŸ”½Those who eliminate the notion of form
can eliminate the entire body.ğŸ”½Among internal and external phenomena,
there is none that is not seen.
The chapter on various meanings also states:ğŸ”½In thought there is thought, neither identical nor separate;
Also not without thought, not excluding thought.ğŸ”½Thus equally excluding the thought of form,
There is no attachment to its causes and conditions.
What is the difference in meaning of these various statements?
The answer is: This refers to the ability to dispel accumulated forms and prevent them from appearing.
It is called excluding the thought of form.
The chapter on various meanings by VÄrá¹£agaá¹‡ya states:
Cutting off desire for the form realm is called excluding the thought of form.
The Saá¹ƒyukta-Ägama states:
Not taking the form of the lower realms as an object is called excluding the thought of form.
Some say:
This exclusion of the thought of form is in the fourth meditative absorption.
The chapter on various meanings by VÄrá¹£agaá¹‡ya states:
Those who exclude the thought of form are in seven stages.
Namely, the preliminary stage of the intermediate concentration, the four meditative absorptions, and the preliminary stage of the sphere of infinite space.
The exclusion of the thought of form as stated in the Saá¹ƒyukta-Ägama
Is also in seven stages.
Namely, the four formless [absorptions] and the three preliminary stages.
Some say:
This elimination of the notion of form is the mindfulness of the body.
The ParÄyana-parivarta-sÅ«tra says:
Eliminating the notion of form refers to the mindfulness of dharmas.
The explanation of eliminating the notion of form in the Saá¹ƒyukta-Ägama
applies to all four establishments of mindfulness.
Some say this elimination of the notion of form is unique,
while the other three are shared.
Some say:
The explanation in the Saá¹ƒyukta-Ägama is shared,
while the other three are unique.
These are called the different explanations.
The four abodes of consciousness and the seven abodes of consciousness.ğŸ”½Are the four included in the seven?
Are the seven included in the four?
And so on, explaining in detail.
Question: Why is this treatise composed?
Answer: In order to analyze the meaning of the sutras.
That is to say, the sutras say:
The four abodes of consciousness, the seven abodes of consciousness, and the nine abodes of sentient beings.
But they are not extensively analyzed,
Nor are they clearly included.
Now, in order to explain them extensively,
And to show their mutual inclusion,
This treatise is composed.
As for the four abodes of consciousness,
As the sutras say:
First, form following consciousness as abode.ğŸ”½Second, feeling following consciousness as abode.
Third, perception following consciousness as abode.
Fourth, volitional formations following consciousness as abode.
As for form following consciousness as abode,
it refers to form that is contaminated, accords with grasping, and is included in sentient beings.
Volitional formations following consciousness as abode are also like this.
As for feeling following consciousness as abode,
it refers to feeling that is contaminated, accords with grasping, and is included in perception.
Following consciousness as abode is also like this.
Other masters say:
As for form following consciousness as abode,
it refers to form that is contaminated, accords with grasping,
and is included in both sentient beings and non-sentient beings.
Volitional formations following consciousness as abode are also like this.
Feeling and perception following consciousness as abode are as explained above.
Question: As for the aggregates that are included in sentient beings,
they are said to be abodes of consciousness.
This matter is possible.
How are the aggregates that are not included in sentient beings called abodes of consciousness?
Answer: There are many kinds of abodes of consciousness,ğŸ”½namely, associated abodes of consciousness,
coexistent abodes of consciousness,ğŸ”½dependent abodes of consciousness,
and objective abodes of consciousness.
The abodes of consciousness that are practiced.
The aggregates that are not sentient beings.
Because they are the objects of consciousness, they are called abodes of consciousness.
The intrinsic nature has already been explained.
The causes and conditions should be explained.
For what causes and conditions is it called an abode of consciousness?
The answer is: Consciousness abides in this.
It abides equally, abides closely, therefore it is called an abode of consciousness.
Like the abode of horses, etc. is called the abode of horses, etc.
Some say:
In this, consciousness is moistened by joy and increases and expands, therefore it is called an abode of consciousness.
Some say:
In this, consciousness is moistened by craving and is grasped and not separated from, therefore it is called an abode of consciousness.
Some say:
In this, all contaminated consciousnesses accord with the consciousness that grasps and arises, and attachment abides, increases, and grows, therefore it is called an abode of consciousness.
Why are the uncontaminated dharmas not established as abodes of consciousness?
The answer is: Because the uncontaminated dharmas do not have the characteristics of abodes of consciousness.
Furthermore, if a dharma can increase existence,ğŸ”½can grasp existence,
can abide in existence,
it is established as an abode of consciousness.
All pure dharmas can diminish existence,ğŸ”½can oppose existence,
can destroy existence,
therefore they are not abodes of consciousness.
Moreover, if dharmas are objects of the view of self,
up to falling into the truths of suffering and accumulation, they are established as abodes of consciousness.
All pure dharmas are not objects of the view of self,
up to not falling into the truths of suffering and accumulation.
Therefore they are not abodes of consciousness.
Some say:
If dharmas are moistened by joy, consciousness increases and expands in them, they are established as abodes of consciousness.
All pure dharmas are contrary to this, therefore they are not abodes of consciousness.
Some say:
If dharmas are moistened by craving, consciousness grasps and does not depart from them, they are established as abodes of consciousness.
All pure dharmas are not like this.
Therefore they are not abodes of consciousness.
Some say:
If dharmas are in accordance with the grasping consciousness, consciousness arises and clings to them,
abiding and increasing, they are established as abodes of consciousness.
All pure dharmas are contrary to this, therefore they are not abodes of consciousness.
Question: Why is consciousness not a station of consciousness?
Answer: Consciousness is established as a station of consciousness for the sake of consciousness.
Just as a king's seat is established for the sake of the king.
It is the same for a king's bed and a king's road.
Just as a road is not a king, and a king is not a road,
but because the king walks on it, it is called a king's road.
In the same way, consciousness is not a station, and a station is not consciousness,
but because consciousness abides in it, it is called a station of consciousness.
Therefore, consciousness is not a station of consciousness.
Some say:
If a dharma is what consciousness rides and controls,
like an elephant, horse, or boat that is ridden and controlled by a person,
that dharma is established as a station of consciousness, not consciousness.
Because consciousness rides and controls consciousness, consciousness is not a station of consciousness.
Furthermore, if a dharma arises, abides, and ceases together with consciousness,
it has a function with respect to consciousness and is established as a station of consciousness.
Consciousness is not like this with respect to consciousness.
Some say:
The dharma of a station of consciousness naturally abides together with consciousness in the present.
It is what consciousness abides in.
Consciousness does not have this matter of obtaining a station of consciousness.
Question: One's own consciousness and the consciousness of others are both in the present.
Why do they not mutually establish consciousness-abiding?
Answer: One's own consciousness is not the abode of one's own consciousness.
It also does not have a different characteristic in the consciousness of others.
Moreover, one's own consciousness is not even the abode of one's own consciousness in terms of intimacy.
How much less so in terms of distance.
Some say:
If a dharma is born through the combination of the three with consciousness,
and there is mutual function, it is established as the abode of consciousness.
Consciousness is not born through the combination of the three with consciousness, and there is no mutual function.
Therefore it is not the abode of consciousness.
Because one's own consciousness abides in it,
one's own aggregates are called the abode of consciousness.
That is to say, the aggregates of the desire realm
are the abode of the consciousness of the desire realm.
The aggregates of the form realm are the abode of the consciousness of the form realm.
The aggregates of the formless realm
are the abode of the consciousness of the formless realm.
The aggregates of the first meditative absorption
are the abode of the consciousness of the first meditative absorption.ğŸ”½Up to the aggregates of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception
are the abode of the consciousness of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
Question: When one born in the desire realm gives rise to a pure mind of the form or formless realms and makes it present,
are the two present aggregates an abode of consciousness?
Answer: It should be said that they are an abode of consciousness.
Question: Consciousness without commonality abides in the middle.
How is it called an abode of consciousness?
Answer: Because it obtains the characteristics of an abode of consciousness.
It means that consciousness with commonality does not arise due to other conditions.
Because it is not that this cannot give rise to [consciousness], it is also called an abode of consciousness.
It is like beside a spring or pond,
where elephants, horses, fish, lions, etc. are placed with their mouths as inlets.
When the water does not flow, it is not obstructed by this.
If the water flows, it becomes a support.
Although the water does not flow, it is still called an inlet.
It is the same for that [consciousness].
As for the seven abodes of consciousness,
as explained in the sutras:
There are sentient beings with different bodies and different ideations,
like humans and some gods. This is the first abode of consciousness. As for having form,
it means those sentient beings have form that can be cognized.
They have a body with form.
The aggregates and sense bases of the form realm.
There is the designation of form.
Therefore, it is called having form.
As for sentient beings,
it refers to the meaning of truth and ultimate truth.
Sentient beings cannot be obtained, and do not have a real substance.
However, among the realms, bases, and aggregates,
they are provisionally imagined and designated as sentient beings.
NÄrÄyaá¹‡a.
Mind-born.
Youthful.
Nourishing.
Puggala.ğŸ”½Life-possessor.
Living being.
Therefore, it is called sentient beings.
As for different bodies,
it means those sentient beings have various bodies,
with various appearances, shapes, and differences in form, therefore it is called different bodies.
As for different perceptions,
it means those sentient beings
have perceptions of pleasure,
perceptions of pain,
and perceptions that are neither pleasurable nor painful.
Therefore, it is called different perceptions.
As for humans and some gods,
humans refer to all humans,
and some gods
refer to gods of the desire realm.
This is the first abode of consciousness.
The first is the initial number in the sequence.
The consciousness that abides there refers to the form, feeling, perception, and consciousness associated with it.
The meaning of the abodes of consciousness has already been explained above.
Beings with form, with different bodies and the same perception,
like the BrahmakÄyika gods.
This refers to the second abode of consciousness, which arose at the beginning.
Beings with form, etc., are as explained above.
The same perception means
that the perception of those beings is the same, without difference.
Like the BrahmakÄyika gods means
that this shows the gods of the Brahma world.
This refers to the second abode of consciousness, which arose at the beginning.
This refers to the defiled perception that arose at the beginning of their birth.
Later, their perception becomes different.ğŸ”½This is the second abode of consciousness.
The second abode of consciousness is as explained above.
As explained above.
Beings with form, with the same body and different perceptions,
like the Ä€bhÄsvara gods.
This is the third abode of consciousness.
Beings with form, etc., are as explained above.
The same body means
that those beings have one kind of body.
One kind of appearance, shape, and form, without difference.
Different perceptions means
It means that those sentient beings have the thought of pleasure and the thought of neither suffering nor pleasure.
Because those gods are already disgusted with the faculty of joy in the fundamental stage,ğŸ”½they manifest the faculty of equanimity in the neighboring stage.
Having become disgusted with the faculty of equanimity in the neighboring stage,
they manifest the faculty of joy in the fundamental stage.
Like a wealthy person,

having become disgusted with the pleasures of desire, they delight in abiding in the pleasure of the Dharma; having become disgusted with the pleasure of the Dharma, they delight in abiding in the pleasures of desire.
Like the gods of extreme radiance.
This shows the gods of the second meditative absorption.
Sentient beings with form, with a single body and a single perception,
like the gods of universal purity.
This is the fourth abode of consciousness.
Having form, etc., is as explained above.
Single perception means
that those sentient beings have a single, undifferentiated, non-obscuring and indeterminate perception.
Like the gods of universal purity.
This shows the gods of the third meditative absorption.
Sentient beings without form, having transcended all perceptions of form,
having caused the perceptions of obstruction to disappear,
not attending to the perception of difference,
Entering boundless space,
fully abiding in the sphere of boundless space,
like the gods of the sphere of boundless space,
this is the fifth abode of consciousness.
Because all beings in the sphere of boundless space of the formless realm have transcended it.
Entering boundless consciousness,
fully abiding in the sphere of boundless consciousness,
like the gods of the sphere of boundless consciousness,
this is the sixth abode of consciousness.
Because all beings in the sphere of boundless consciousness of the formless realm have transcended it.
Entering the sphere of nothingness, fully abiding in the sphere of nothingness,
like the gods of the sphere of nothingness,
this is the seventh abode of consciousness.
Here, the formless ones
means those beings who have no form to be cognized,
who have no physical form,
and who have no aggregates or sense bases of the formless realm.
Because there is no designation of form, they are called formless.
The beings and so forth are as explained before.
All have transcended the sphere of boundless space and so forth are as explained in other places.
The abodes of consciousness
It refers to the feeling, conception, volition, and consciousness associated with it.
Why is there difference in body in the first dhyÄna but not in the higher stages?
The answer is: because in the first dhyÄna the king, ministers, and masses are established with distinctions.
Namely, the Great BrahmÄ King often gathers with the BrahmÄ Attendants and the BrahmÄ Masses.
In the middle, various appearances and forms are displayed.
The clothes and language have different distinctions.
The higher stages are not like this.
Some say:
In the first dhyÄna, there is no difference between superior, middling, and inferior feelings.
Because of the ripening of karma, the body has differences.
The higher stages are not like this.
Some say:
In the first dhyÄna, there is applied thought and sustained thought.
Because of the ripening of karma, the body has differences.
The higher stages are not like this.
Some say:
In the first dhyÄna, there is indication and non-indication.
Because of the ripening of karma, the body has differences.
The higher stages are not like this.
Some say:
In the first dhyÄna, there is the association of the four consciousnesses.
Because of the ripening of karma, the body has differences.
The higher stages are not like this.
Some say:
In the first dhyÄna, there are three types of feelings associated with it.
Because of the ripening of karma, the body is different.
The upper stages are not like this.
Due to these and other various reasons,
the body of the first dhyÄna is different, while the bodies of the upper stages are the same.
Moreover, in the first dhyÄna,
it is said to be the same in terms of conceptualization due to defiled conceptualization.
In the second dhyÄna,
it is said to be different in terms of conceptualization due to wholesome conceptualization.
In the third dhyÄna,
it is said to be the same in terms of conceptualization due to the unobscured indeterminate ripening of conceptualization.
Why are the evil destinies,
the fourth dhyÄna,
and the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception
all not established as abodes of consciousness?
Some say:
They should also be established as abodes of consciousness.
But they are not established,
this is a partial explanation.
Venerable Vasumitra says:
This is what the World-Honored One said in brief.
However, the evil destinies and so forth are included in this.
It should be known that the evil destinies are included in the first abode of consciousness.
The fourth meditation includes the next three.
The sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception includes the last three.
Why is this so?
Because the realms are the same.
Some say:
If a place has two kinds of consciousness that can be mostly obtained,
it is established as an abode of consciousness.
One is consciousness that is embraced by craving,
and the other is consciousness that is embraced by views.
The evil destinies and the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,
consciousness that is embraced by craving can mostly not be obtained.
In the fourth meditation,
consciousness that is embraced by views can mostly not be obtained.
Therefore it is not an abode of consciousness.
Some say:
If a place has three kinds of consciousness that can mostly be obtained,
it is established as an abode of consciousness.ğŸ”½One is consciousness that is eliminated by seeing,
the other is consciousness that is eliminated by cultivation,
and the third is undestroyed consciousness.
The evil destinies,
and the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,
undestroyed consciousness can not be obtained together.
The fourth meditative absorption.
The consciousness to be eliminated by insight is mostly unobtainable.
Therefore, it is not a station of consciousness.
Question: Aren't there ordinary beings in the fourth meditative absorption?
Isn't the consciousness to be eliminated by insight obtainable?
Answer: Although it exists, it is mostly unobtainable in that stage.
Because the five pure abodes are completely devoid of it.
Question: In the human realm and the desire realm heavens,
The undestroyed consciousness is also unobtainable.
It should not be a station of consciousness.
Answer: There are two kinds of obtainability.
One is the obtainability of the intrinsic nature.
The other is the obtainability of the basis.
In the human realm and the desire realm heavens,
Although the undestroyed consciousness is not obtainable in terms of its intrinsic nature,
It is established as a station of consciousness because its basis is obtainable.
Question: Aren't the consciousnesses that are not eliminated also obtainable as the basis in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception?
Because there are those who attain arhatship after being born there.
Answer: Although it exists, it is not the majority.
Because one who is born there temporarily gives rise to the noble path,
Obtains the fruit of arhatship, and then
because nirvana is not manifest.
Some say:
If a place has the six kinds of consciousness that can be mostly obtained, it is established as a dwelling of consciousness.
That is, the consciousness to be eliminated by seeing suffering,
up to the consciousness to be eliminated by cultivation,
and the uninterrupted consciousness.
The evil destinies,
the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,
the uninterrupted consciousness cannot be obtained.
The fourth meditation,
the consciousness to be eliminated by the first four,
cannot be mostly obtained, therefore it is not a dwelling of consciousness.
The questions and answers should be understood as before.
Some say:
If a place is where consciousness delights in dwelling, it is established as a dwelling of consciousness.
In the evil destinies, consciousness is oppressed by suffering and does not delight in dwelling.
The bliss of the fourth meditation,
because it is changeable, consciousness does not abide in it.
That is, the ordinary beings either delight in entering the formless realm,
or delight in entering the state of non-perception,
or delight in causing consciousness to cease.
If the noble ones either delight in entering the formless realm,
or delight in entering the pure abodes,
Or they delight in entering the remainderless [nirvana].
The sphere of neither perception nor non-perception.
Because it is extremely tranquil and the mind is extremely weak, consciousness does not delight in abiding there.
Some say:
If there is a place where consciousness cannot be destroyed,
it is established as a station of consciousness.
In the evil destinies, there is extreme suffering.
In the fourth meditative absorption,
there is the attainment of non-perception.
The attainment of non-perception and the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception,
there is the attainment of cessation.
Because they can destroy consciousness, they are not stations of consciousness.
Some say:ğŸ”½If there is a place where,
due to two reasons, it gives rise to a superior consciousness of a different kind,
causing it to appear, it is established as a station of consciousness.
First, due to meditative absorption.
Second, due to rebirth.
The evil destinies,
the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception,
lack both of these.
Although the fourth meditative absorption
has meditative absorption, it lacks rebirth.
Some say:
The two factors are absent in the evil destinies. Although the fourth trance state has concentration, it lacks birth.
Although the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception has birth, it lacks concentration.
Due to these various causes and conditions,
the evil destinies and so forth are not abodes of consciousness.
Question: Why is consciousness not an abode of consciousness among the four abodes of consciousness?
Why is consciousness an abode of consciousness among the seven abodes of consciousness?
Answer: The four abodes of consciousness are established due to separate causes.
The seven abodes of consciousness are established due to separate causes.
That is to say, if there is a dharma that consciousness rides and controls,
that which accompanies consciousness, is close to consciousness, and is in union with consciousness,
the four abodes of consciousness are established.
Consciousness does not have such a relationship with consciousness,
so it is not established as being among the four abodes of consciousness.
If a dharma is a cause or effect of consciousness,
it is mutually supported and the seven abodes of consciousness are established.
Consciousness has such a relationship with consciousness,
so it is established as being among the seven abodes of consciousness.
The nine abodes of sentient beings are as explained in the sutras.
As a sutra says:
Sentient beings with form have different bodies and different perceptions.
Like humans and some gods.
This is the first abode of sentient beings.
Sentient beings with form have different bodies but the same perception.
Like the BrahmakÄyika gods.
This is the second abode of sentient beings.
Sentient beings with form have the same body but different perceptions.
Like the Ä€bhÄsvara gods.
This is the third abode of sentient beings.
Sentient beings with form have the same body and the same perception.
Like the Åšubhaká¹›tsna gods.
This is the fourth abode of sentient beings.
Having form, etc., is as explained above.
As for the abodes of sentient beings,
It refers to the form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness associated with them.
Moreover, it is where sentient beings dwell,ğŸ”½Where they reside,
Where they stay,
Where they are born,
Therefore it is called the abode of sentient beings.
Sentient beings with form,
Without thought, without distinct thoughts,
Like the gods of the non-percipient sentient beings.
This is the fifth abode of sentient beings.
Having form, etc., is as explained above.
As for being without thought,
Because for a long time in that place, thoughts and so forth cease.
Therefore, by this meaning, it is called the heaven of beings without thought.
Beings in the formless realm transcend all conceptual thoughts of form.
Therefore, all conceptual thoughts of resistance are concealed,
and they do not pay attention to conceptual thoughts of diversity.
They enter the sphere of infinite space, abiding in fullness.
Like the gods who follow the sphere of infinite space,
this is the sixth abode of beings.
Beings in the formless realm
transcend all the sphere of infinite space.
They enter infinite consciousness,
the sphere of infinite consciousness, abiding in fullness.
Like the gods who follow the sphere of infinite consciousness,
this is the seventh abode of beings.
Beings in the formless realm transcend all the sphere of infinite consciousness.
They enter the sphere of nothingness,
the sphere of nothingness, abiding in fullness.
Like the gods who follow the sphere of nothingness,
this is the eighth abode of beings.
Because all formless sentient beings transcend the sphere of nothingness.
They enter the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception and abide there.
Like the gods of the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception.
This is the ninth abode of sentient beings.
The formless realm is as explained before.
All transcend the sphere of nothingness, as explained elsewhere.
Question: Why are the evil destinies and the sphere of non-perception not included?
Why are the gods of the heaven of vast fruit and so on not abodes of sentient beings?
Answer: Some say:
They should also be established as abodes of sentient beings.
But they are not established.
This is a remainder of the teaching.
Venerable Vasumitra says:
This is the concise teaching of the World-Honored One.
However, the evil destinies and so on are included here.
That is to say, the various evil destinies should be known to be included in the first abode of sentient beings.
The sphere of non-perception is not included.
The gods of the heaven of vast fruit and so on should be known to be included in the fifth abode of sentient beings.
Why is it so?
Because the realms are the same.
Some say:
If a place is where other pleasures come to dwell,
and having dwelt there,
one does not enjoy moving,
that place can be established as a realm of sentient beings.
In the evil destinies, both are not so.
But only by the power of karma does it cause one to go and cause one to abide.
If it is according to one's desires, it does not abide for a moment, and therefore it is not established.
In the fourth meditative absorption, excluding the heaven of non-perception.
Although pleasures come, they prefer to move.
Like the people in a border city do not enjoy living there.
It is said that ordinary beings either enjoy the formless realm,
or enjoy non-perception.
If they are noble ones, they either enjoy the pure abodes,
or proceed to nirvana.
Like a border city is constantly invaded by thieves, neighboring enemies, and so forth.
The wealth and pleasures of a noble family move to other places.
Although a small portion is left behind to serve as a garrison,
there are merchants who come seeking to obtain goods.
The garrison people say:
This place has many disasters, and we cannot look after you.
The merchants all said:
This is not a city.
In this way, the heavens not included in the formless realm,
Driven by delusion and karma, are always changing and moving.
Therefore, they are not said to be the abodes of sentient beings.
The three kinds of intrinsic natures have been distinguished.

The reasons for this are explained in detail as before.

Question: Are the seven abodes of consciousness and the nine abodes of sentient beingsğŸ”½included in the seven,
or are the seven included in the nine?
Answer: The nine include the seven,
but the seven do not include the nine.
What is not included?
Answer: Two places.
Namely, the non-perceptual heavenly realm,
and the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
The reason for this is also as explained above.
Question: Why did the World-Honored One
in the non-perceptual heavens
often speak of them as abodes?
Answer: There are non-Buddhist practitioners
who take these two realms as liberation.
The Buddha, in order to refute them, speaks of them as abodes of birth.
Some say:
Non-Buddhist practitioners take these two realms as the most tranquil,
the Buddha speaks of them as abodes.
It is clear that these are agitated and not tranquil.
This is because they are the places of transmigration in the realms, destinies, and births.
Some say:
Non-Buddhists grasp these two places
as true liberation, from which there is never regression.
Therefore the Buddha said they are places of regression
and not true liberation.
It means that after falling from the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception,
one is often reborn in lower realms.
After falling from the heaven of non-perception, one necessarily is reborn in the desire realm.
Some say:
The lifespans of the beings in those two heavens are extremely long.
Non-Buddhists often grasp them as true nirvÄá¹‡a.
The heaven of non-perception is the place of rebirth for only ordinary beings.
The lifespan there is the longest.
The heaven of neither perception nor non-perception has the longest lifespan of all places of rebirth.
Therefore the Buddha said they are impermanent places.
Some say:ğŸ”½The World-Honored One has proclaimed all nine abodes of sentient beings
using two names.
He uses two names for the first seven,
calling them abodes of consciousness and abodes of sentient beings.
The other two are also called by two names.
They are called abodes and abodes of sentient beings.
Other masters say:
The Buddha includes the abodes of consciousness and the abodes of sentient beings in each other.
The remaining incomplete ones are only two abodes.
They should not be explained differently.
Because the formless concentrations such as infinite space are also called abodes.
Some say:
Because the place of birth is the final result of diligent practice, it is called an abode.
That is, only ordinary beings, whose place of birth is the final result of diligent practice,
are the non-percipient celestials.
Among all places of birth that are the final result of diligent practice,
the peak of existence is the final one.

and the past and future are not real,
the intention is to show that the causes and conditions of the past and future are real, and therefore this treatise is composed.
